Mr. Quayle
February 26, 1969
The question becomes: What stations are to be funded?
How can a public radio station be identified?
The six criteria listed here might be utilized. There
may be others.
1* Transmitter Power: Station* with limited power
provide limited service. The case is best stated by
quoting from Report No. 7834 dated January 23, 1969
and released by the Federal Communications Commission in
denying the rulemaking petition for increase of trans¬
mitter power for educational Class D FM stations. The
report says, in part:
"Rules providing for licensing of low-powered non-commer¬
cial educational FM stations, the Commission noted, were
adopted on August 19, 1948 (FCC 48-1958 Docket 0948).
The stations were not intended as alternates to regular
educational FM broadcast stations but were considered
substitut4s for wired carrier "campus'* systems using AM
broadcast channels ..."
"The service ... was intended to be limited to a small
area, usually a college or university campus or the im¬
mediately surrounding area."
"The simplicity of the present provision has served
the intended purpose of the rule ...”
"When better coverage is desired, regular non-commercial
educational FM broadcast stations may be used to provide
a stibbfe&attal improvement (in power and coverage)."
It would seem that the guidelines are rather precisely
established and that transmitter power is an appropriate
criterion for identifying public radio stations.
2. Coverage. Unless the station is providing coverage
to substantial numbers of people, its public function is
obviously limited. There is obvious corollary between
transmitter power and coverage but both should be con¬
sidered. For example, in certain isolated rural areas,
a 10 watt FM station may provide the only coverage (and
thus the only service) available from a non-commercial
